title: Helen Mirren says men putting their arms around women is like ownership |
text:
MEN, listen up: while you may think that slinging your arm around your girlfriend’s shoulders is endearing and protective, to Helen Mirren, it is nothing more than claiming “ownership” over your partner.
In a tell-all interview with Mail on Sunday You magazine , the talented actress and style icon revealed her irritation at seeing men try to claim women as their property.
“It annoys me when I see men with their arm slung around their girlfriend’s shoulders,” she said.
“When you’re young, you want the guy to take your hand and look after you.
“But when I see girls being leaned on, I want to say, ‘Tell him to get his damned arm off your shoulder’.”
Assertiveness ... Helen Mirren says young women should say “f*** off” much more. Picture: Frank Gunn/The Canadian Press via AP Source: AP
Speaking with the benefit of age — Mirren has bucked the trend of the ageing, invisible actor and is still in demand at age 70 — Mirren has also slammed society for treating women as children, especially with regards to their bodies and sexual freedoms.
“Women are still toddlers in this modern world, trying to find their position in the age of sexual liberation, birth control, education and financial independence,” she lamented.
“We’re still finding our path. And yes, we’re making a lot of mistakes along the way.
“At 70-years-old, if I could give my younger self one piece of advice, it would be to use the words “f*** off” much more frequently.”
As arguably the most vocal voice of older women, Mirren is also not shy about her sex life, which she says “just gets better with age”.
In demand ... Helen Mirren and Ryan Reynolds in a scene from the film Woman in Gold. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
“I always think of this scientific survey carried out among American college kids in the 1960s [where] they were all happy to talk about their own sex life. Then they were asked about their parents’ sex lives — and oh, they were horrified!” she said.
“The young always want to feel as though they’re the ones to do everything first. But naturally, it’s all been done before.”
Mirren has often spoken out about feminism and women, slamming Hollywood’s sexist double standards when it comes to female roles (“It’s f***ing outrageous. It’s ridiculous. Honestly, it’s so annoying. We all watched James Bond as he got more and more geriatric, and his girlfriends got younger and younger. It’s like ‘grrrr’. It’s so annoying”) as well as telling the The Times in April that calling women “sassy” and “feisty” was “insulting”.
“Only women are feisty,” she said. “It just makes me gag.”
“We need new words for female power and funniness and smartness.”
Controversially, she also said that women were often crueller than men, adding that “level of cruelty and judgementalism” of women towards other women, particularly in the age of social media, was more damaging “than from men to women nowadays”.
